sp.l: Certain they'll tempt us strongly: beside the glory
Which women may affect: they are handsome gentlemen,
Every part speaks: nor is it one denial,
Nor two, nor ten: from every look we give 'em,
They'll frame a hope: even from our prayers, promises,

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Let 'em feed so, and be fat: there is no fear wench,
If thou beest fast to thyself.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I hope I shall be:
And your example will work more. Enter Theod.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thou shalt not want it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How do you sir, can you lend a man an angel?
I hear you let out money.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Very well sir,
You are pleasantly disposed: I am glad to see it,
Can you lend me your patience, and be ruled by me?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Is't come to patience now?

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Is 't not a virtue?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I know not. I never found it so.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: That's because
Thy anger ever knows, and not thy judgement.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I know you have been rifled.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Nothing less boy:
Lord what opinions these vain people publish?
Rifled of what?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Study your virtue patience,
It may get mustard to your meat. Why in such haste sir,
Sent ye for me?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: For this end only, Theodore,
To wait upon your sisters to the court;
I am commanded they live there.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Toth' court sir?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Toth' court I say.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And must I wait upon 'em?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis most fit ye should, ye are their brother.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Is this the business? I had thought your mind sir
Had been set forward on some noble action,
Something had truly stirred ye. Toth' court with these?
Why they are your daughter's sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: All this I know sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The good old woman on a bed he threw.
Toth' court?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thou art not mad.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Nor drunk as you are:
Drunk with your duty sir: do you call it duty?
A pox of duty, what can these do there?
What should they do? Can ye look babies sisters
In the young gallants eyes, and twirl their bandstrings?
Can ye ride out to air yourselves? pray sir,
Be serious with me: do you speak this truly?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why didst thou never hear of women
Yet at court boy?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Yes, and good women too, very good women,
Excellent honest women: but are you sure sir,
That these will prove so?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: There's the danger brother.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: God a mercy wench, thou hast a grudging of it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now be you serious sir, and observe what I say,
Do it, and do it handsomely: go with 'em.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: With all my heart sir; I am in no fault now;
If they be thought whores for being in my company;
Pray write upon their backs, they are my sisters,
And where I shall deliver 'em.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ye are wondrous jocund,
But prithee tell me, art thou so lewd a fellow,
I never knew thee fail a truth,

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am a soldier,
And spell you what that means.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A soldier?
What dost thou make of me?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Your palate's down sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I thank ye sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Come, shall we to this matter?
You will to court?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: If you will please to honour us.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I'll honour ye, I warrant: I'll set ye off
With such a lustre wenches: alas poor Viola,
Thou art a fool, thou criest for eating white-bread:
Be a good housewife of thy tears, and save 'em,
Thou wilt have time enough to shed 'em sister.
Do you weep too? nay then I'll fool no more.
Come worthy sisters, since it must be so,
And since he thinks it fit to try your virtues,
Be you as strong to truth, as I to guard ye,
And this old gentleman shall have joy of ye. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene 3.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Burris take you ten thousand of those crowns,
And those two chains of pearl they hold the richest,
I give 'em ye.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I humbly thank your grace;
And may your great example work in me
That noble charity to men more worthy,
And of more wants.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You bear a good mind Burris;
Take twenty thousand now: be not so modest,
It shall be so, I give 'em: go, there's my ring for't.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.p: Heaven bless your highness ever. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You are honest.

div.stage: Enter Alinda, and Putsky at door.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: They're coming now to court, as fair as virtue:
Two brighter stars never rose here.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Peace, I have it,
And what my art can do; the Duke —

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I am gone,
Remember. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am counselled to the full sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My pretty mistress, whither lies your business?
How kindly I should take this, were it to me now?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I must confess immediately to your grace,
At this time.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You have no address, I do believe ye,
I would ye had.

sp.speaker: Al
sp.l: 'Twere too much boldness sir,
Upon so little knowledge, less deserving.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You'll make a perfect courtier.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A very poor one.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: A very fair one sweet: come hither to me.
What killing eyes this wench has? in his glory
Not the bright sun, when the Sirian star reigns,
Shines half so fiery.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why does your grace so view me?
Nothing but common handsomeness dwells here sir,
Scarce that: your grace is pleased to mock my meanness.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thou shalt not go: I do not lie unto thee,
In my eye thou appearest —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Dim not the sight sir,
I am too dull an object.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Canst thou love me?
Canst thou love him will honour thee?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I can love,
And love as you do too: but 'twill not show well:
Or if it do show here where all light lustres,
Tinsel affections, make a glorious glistering,
'Twill halt ith' handsome way.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Are ye so cunning?
Dost think I love not truly?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No, ye cannot,
You never travelled that way yet: pray pardon me,
I prate so boldly to you.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: There's no harm done:
But what's your reason, sweet?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I would tell your grace,
But happily —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It shall be pleasing to me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I should love you again, and then you would hate me.
With all my service I should follow ye,
And through all dangers.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This would more provoke me,
More make me see thy worths,
More make me meet 'em.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You should do so, if ye did well and truly.
But though ye be a prince, and have power in ye,
Power of example too, ye have failed and faltered.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Give me example where?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You had a mistress,
O heaven, so bright, so brave a dame, so lovely,
In all her life so true.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: A mistress?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That served ye with that constancy, that care,
That loved your will, and wooed it too.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What mistress?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That nursed your honour up, held fast your virtue,
And when she kissed increased, not stole your goodness.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And I neglected her?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Lost her, forsook her,
Wantonly slung her off.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What was her name?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Her name as lovely as herself, as noble,
And in it all that's excellent.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What was it?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Her name was Beau-desert:
Do you know her now sir?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Beau-desert? I not remember —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I know you do not:
Yet she has a plainer name; lord Archas service;
Do you yet remember her? there was a mistress
Fairer than women, far fonder to you sir,
Then mothers to their firstborn joys: can you love?
Dare you profess that truth to me a stranger,
A thing of no regard, no name, no lustre,
When your most noble love you have neglected,
A beauty all the world would woo and honour?
Would you have me credit this? think ye can love me,
And hold ye constant, when I have read this story?
Is't possible you should ever favour me,
To a slight pleasure prove a friend, and fast too,
When, where you were most tied, most bound to benefit,
Bound by the chains of honesty and honour,
You have broke and boldly too? I am a weak one,
Armed only with my fears: I beseech your grace
Tempt me no further.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Who taught you this lesson?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Woeful experience sir: if you seek a fair one,
Worthy your love, if yet you have that perfect,
Two daughters of his ruined virtue now
Arrive at court, excellent fair indeed sir,
But this will be the plague on't, they're excellent honest.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I love thy face.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Upon my life ye cannot.
I do not love it myself sir, 'tis a lewd one,
So truly ill art cannot mend it; 'Sod if 'twere handsome,
At least if I thought so, you should hear me talk sir
In a new strain; and though ye are a prince,
Make ye petition to me too, and wait my answers;
Yet of my conscience I should pity ye,
After some ten years siege.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Prithee do now.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What would ye do?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why I would lie with ye.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I do not think ye would.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Introth I would wench.
Here, take this jewel.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Out upon't that's scurvy.
Nay, if we do, sure we'll do for good fellowship,
For pure love, or nothing: thus you shall be sure sir
You shall not pay too dear for't.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sure I cannot.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: By'r lady but ye may: when ye have found me able,
To do your work well, ye may pay my wages.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why does your grace start back?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I ha' seen that shakes me:
Chills all my blood: oh where is faith or goodness?
Alinda thou art false, false, false thou fair one,
Wickedly false; and (Woe is me) I see it.
For ever false.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am gladded has taken thus right. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I'll go ask my lady, sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Whether I shall lie with ye, or no: if I find her willing .
For look ye sir, I have sworn, while I am in her service —
('twas a rash oath I must confess.)

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thou mockest me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why, would ye lie with me, if I were willing?
Would you abuse my weakness?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I would piece it,
And make it stronger.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I humbly thank your highness,
When you piece me, you must piece me to my coffin:
When you have got my maidenhead, I take it,
'Tis not an inch of an ape's tail will restore it;
I love ye, and I honour ye, but this way
I'll neither love nor serve ye:
Heaven change your mind sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And thine too:
For it must be changed, it shall be. Exit.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter Borosky, Burris, Theodore, Viola, and Honora.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: They are goodly gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: They are,
Wondrous sweet women both.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Does your lordship like 'em?
They are my sister's sir; good lusty lasses,
They'll do their labour well, I warrant ye
You'll find no bedstraw here sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thank ye brother.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This is not so strongly built: but she is good mettle,
Of a good stirring strain too: she goes tith sir. Enter 2. Gent.
Here they be gentlemen must make ye merry,
The toys you wot of: do you like their complexions?
They be no Moors: what think ye of this hand gentlemen?
Here's a white altar for your sacrifice:
A thousand kisses here. Nay, keep off yet gentlemen,
Let's start first, and have fair play: what would ye give now
To turn the globe up, and find the rich Moluccas?
To pass the straits? here (Do ye itch) by st. Nicolas,
Here's that will make ye scratch and claw,
Claw my fine gentlemen, move ye in divers sorts:
Pray ye let me request ye, to forget
To say your prayers, whilst these are courtiers;
Or if ye needs will think of heaven, let it be no higher
Than their eyes?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: How will ye have 'em bestowed sir?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Even how your lordship please,
So you do not bake 'em.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Bake 'em.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: They are too high a meat that way, they run to jelly.
But if you'll have 'em for your own diet, take my counsel,
Stew 'em between two featherbeds.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Please you colonel
To let 'em wait upon the Princess?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Yes sir,
And thank your honour too: but then happily,
These noble gentlemen shall have no access to 'em,
And to have 'em buy new clothes, study new faces,
And keep a stinking stir with themselves for nothing,
'Twill not be well i'faith: they have kept their bodies,
And been at charge for baths: do you see that shirt there?
Way but the moral meaning, 'twill be grievous:
Alas, I brought 'em to delight these gentlemen,
I weigh their wants by mine: I brought 'em wholesome,
Wholesome, and young my lord, and two such blessings
They will not light upon again in ten year.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: 'Tis fit they wait upon her.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They are fit for any thing.
They'll wait upon a man, they are not bashful,
Carry his cloak, or untie his points, or any thing,
Drink drunk, and take tobacco; the familiarst fools —
This wench will leap over stools too, and sound a trumpet,
Wrestle, and pitch the bar; they are finely brought up,

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ladies, ye are bound to your brother,
And have much cause to thank him:
I'll ease ye of this charge, and to the Princess,
So please you, I'll attend 'em.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Thank your lordship:
If there be e'er a private corner as ye go sir,
A foolish lobby out oth' way, make danger,
Try what they are, try.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ye are a merry gentleman.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I would fain be your honour's kinsman.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ye are to cursed sir.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Farewell wenches, keep close your ports, you're washed else.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Brother bestow your fears where they are needful.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Honour thy name is, and I hope thy nature.
Go after, gentlemen, go, get a snatch if you can,
Yond old erra pater will never please 'em.
Alas I brought 'em for you, but see the luck on't,
I swear I meant as honestly towards ye —
Nay do not cry good gentlemen: a little counsel
Will do no harm: they'll walk abroad ith' evenings,
Ye may surprise 'em easily, they wear no pistols.
Set down your minds in metre, flowing metre,
And get some good old linen woman to deliver it,
That has the trick on't: you cannot fail:
Farewell gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You have frighted off these flesh-flies.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Flesh-flies indeed my lord. Enter a serv.
And it must be very stinking flesh they will not seize on.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Your lordship bid me bring this casket.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Yes. Good colonel
Commend me to your worthy father, and as a pledge
He ever holds my love, and service to him,
Deliver him this poor, but hearty token,
And where I may be his —

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Ye are too noble;
A wonder here my lord, that dare be honest,
When all men hold it vicious: I shall deliver it,
And with it your most noble love. Your servant. Ex. Bur.
Were there but two more such at court, 'twere sainted,
This will buy brawn this Christmas yet, and muscadine. Ex.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter ancient, crying brooms, and after him severally, four soldiers, crying other things. Borosky and gent. over the stage observing them.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: Broom, broom, the bonny broom,
Come buy my birchen broom,
Ith' wars we have no more room,
Buy all my bonny broom.
For a kiss take two;
If those will not do,
For a little, little pleasure,
Take all my whole treasure:
If all these will not do't,
Take the broom-man to boot.
Broom, broom, the bonny broom.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: The wars are done and gone,
And soldiers now neglected, pedlars are,
Come maidens, come alone,
For I can show you handsome, handsome ware.
Powders for, for the head,
And drinks for your bed,
To make ye blithe and bonnie.
As well in the night we soldiers can fight,
And please a young wench as any.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: I have fine potatoes,
Ripe potatoes.

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: Will ye buy any honesty, come away,
I sell it openly by day,
I bring no forced light, nor no candle
To cozen ye; come buy and handle:
This will show the great man good,
The tradesman where he swears and lies,
Each lady of a noble blood,
The city dame to rule her eyes:
Ye are rich men now: come buy, and then
I'll make ye richer, honest-men.

sp.speaker: 4 soldier
sp.l: Have ye any cracked maidenheads, to new leech or mend?
Have ye any old maidenheads to sell or to change?
Bring 'em to me with a little pretty gin,
I'll clout 'em, I'll mend 'em, I'll knock in a pin,
Shall make 'em as good maids again,
As ever they have been.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: What means all this, why do y' sell brooms ancient?
Is it in wantonness, or want?

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: The only reason is,
To sweep your lordship's conscience: here's one for the nonce.
Gape sir, you have swallowed many a goodlier matter —
The only casting for a crazy conscience.

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.p: Will your lordship buy any honesty? 'twill be worth your money.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: Honesty my lord, 'tis here in a quill.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: Take heed you open it not, for 'tis so subtle,
The least puff of wind will blow it out oth' kingdom.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Will your lordship to taste a fine potato?
'Twill advance your withered state.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: Fill your honour full of most noble itches,
And make Jack dance in your lordship's breeches.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: If your daughters on their beds,
Have bowed, or cracked their maidenheads;
If in a coach with two much tumbling,
They chance to cry, fie, foe, what fumbling;
If her foot slip, and down fall she,
And break her leg above the knee,
The one and thirtieth of February let this be ta'en,
And they shall be arrant maids again.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ye are brave soldiers; keep your wantonness,
A winter will come on to shake this wilfulness.
Disport yourselves, and when you want your money —Ex.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: Broom, broom, etc.Exit singing.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You must not be so fearful, little one,
Nor lady you so sad, you will never make courtiers
With these dull sullen thoughts; this place is pleasure,
Preserved to that use, so inhabited;
And those that live here, live delightful, joyful:
These are the gardens of Adonis, ladies,
Where all sweets to their free and noble uses,
Grow ever young and courted.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Bless me heaven,
Can things of her years arrive at these rudiments?
By your leave fair gentlewoman, how long have you been here?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Faith much about a week.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You have studied hard,
And by my faith arrived at a great knowledge.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Were not you bashful at first?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ay, ay, for an hour or two:
But when I saw people laughed at me for it,
And thought it a dull breeding —

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You are governed here then
Much after the men's opinions.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ever lady.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: And what they think is honourable. —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Most precisely
We follow with all faith.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: A goodly catechism.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But bashful for an hour or two?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Faith to say true,
I do not think I was so long: for look ye,
'Tis to no end here, put on what shape ye will,
And sour yourself with never so much austerity,
You shall be courted in the same, and won too,
'Tis but some two hours more; and so much time lost,
Which we hold precious here: in so much time now
As I have told you this, you may lose a servant,
Your age, nor all your art can e'er recover.
Catch me occasion as she comes, hold fast there,
Till what you do affect is ripened to ye.
Has the Duke seen ye yet?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What if he have not?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You do your beauties too much wrong, appearing
So full of sweetness, newness; set so richly,
As if a council beyond nature framed ye.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: If we were thus? say heaven had given these blessings,
Must we turn these to sin-oblations?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How foolishly this country way shows in ye?
How full of phlegm? do you come here to pray ladies.
You had best cry, stand away, let me alone gentlemen,
I'll tell my father else.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: This woman's naught sure,
A very naughty woman.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Come, say on friend,
I'll be instructed by ye.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You'll thank me for't.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Either I or the devil shall: the Duke you were speaking of.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Tis well remembered: yes, let him first see you,
Appear not openly till he has viewed ye.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: He's a very noble prince they say.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O wondrous gracious;
And as you may deliver yourself at the first viewing.
For look ye, you must bear yourself; yet take heed
It be so seasoned with a sweet humility,
And graced with such a bounty in your beauty —

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: But I hope he will offer me no ill?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No, no:
'Tis like he will kiss ye, and play with ye.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Play with me, how?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why, good lord, that you are such a fool now.
No harm assure yourself.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Will ye play with me too?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Look babies in your eyes, my pretty sweet one:
There's a fine sport: do you know your lodgings yet?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I hear of none.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I do then, they are handsome,
Convenient for access.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Access?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes little one,
For visitation of those friends and servants,
Your beauties shall make choice of: friends and visits:
Do not you know those uses? Alas poor novice;
There's a close couch or two, handsomely placed too.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: What are those I pray you?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Who would be troubled with such raw things? they are to lie upon,
And your love by ye; and discourse, and toy in.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Alas I have no love.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You must by any means:
You'll have a hundred, fear not.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Honesty keep me:
What shall I do with all those?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You'll find uses:
Ye are ignorant yet, let time work; you must learn too,
To lie handsomely in your bed a mornings, neatly dressed
In a most curious waistcoat, to set ye off well,
Play with your bracelets, sing you must learn to rhyme to,
And riddle neatly; study the hardest language,
And 'tis no matter whether it be sense, or no,
So it go seemly off. Be sure ye profit
In kissing, kissing sweetly: there lies a main point,
A key that opens to all practic pleasure;
I'll help ye to a friend of mine shall teach ye,
And suddenly: your country way is fulsome.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Have ye schools for all these mysteries?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O yes,
And several hours prefixed to study in:
Ye may have calendars to know the good hour,
And when to take a jewel: for the ill too,
When to refuse, with observations on 'em;
Under what sign 'tis best meeting in an arbour,
And in what bower, and hour it works; a thousand,
When in a coach, when in a private lodging,
With all their virtues.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Have ye studied these?
How beastly they become your youth? how bawdily?
A woman of your tenderness, a teacher,
Teacher of these lewd arts? of your full beauty?
A man made up in lust would loathe this in ye:
The rankest lecher, hate such impudence.
They say the devil can assume heaven's brightness,
And so appear to tempt us: sure thou art no woman.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I joy to find ye thus.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thou hast no tenderness,
No reluctation in thy heart: 'tis mischief.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: All's one for that; read these and then be satisfied,
A few more private rules I have gathered for ye,
Read 'em, and well observe 'em: so I leave ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: A wondrous wicked woman: shame go with thee.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: What new Pandora's box is this? I'll see it,
Though presently I tear it. Read thine Viola,
'Tis in our own wills to believe and follow.

body.l: Worthy Honora, as you have begun
In virtues spotless school, so forward run:
Pursue that nobleness, and chaste desire
You ever had, burn in that holy fire;
And a white martyr to fair memory
Give up your name, unsoiled of infamy.

sp.l: How's this? Read yours out sister: this amazes me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Fear not thou yet unblasted violet,
Nor let my wanton words a doubt beget,
Live in that peace and sweetness of thy bud,
Remember whose thou art, and grow still good.
Remember what thou art, and stand a story
Fit for thy noble sex, and thine own glory.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Sure a good woman,
An excellent woman, sister.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: It confounds me;
Let 'em use all their arts, if these be their ends,
The court I say breeds the best foes and friends.
Come, let's be honest wench, and do our best service.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: A most excellent woman, I will love her. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Olimpia with a casket, and Alinda.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Madam, the Duke has sent for the two ladies.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I prithee go: I know thy thoughts are with him.
Go, go Alinda, do not mock me more.
I have found thy heart wench, do not wrong thy mistress,
Thy too much loving mistress: do not abuse her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: By your own fair hands I understand ye not.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: By thy own fair eyes I understand thee too much,
Too far, and built a faith there thou hast ruin.
Go, and enjoy thy wish, thy youth, thy pleasure,
Enjoy the greatness no doubt he has promised,
Enjoy the service of all eyes that see thee,
The glory thou hast aimed at, and the triumph:
Only this last love I ask, forget thy mistress.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O, who has wronged me? who has ruined me?
Poor wretched girl, what poison is slung on thee?
Excellent virtue, from whence flows this anger?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Go, ask my brother, ask the faith thou gavest me,
Ask all my favours to thee, ask my love,
Last, thy forgetfulness of good: then fly me,
For we must part Alinda.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You are weary of me;
I must confess, I was never worth your service,
Your bounteous favours less; but that my duty,
My ready will, and all I had to serve ye —
Oh heaven thou knowest my honesty.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: No more:
Take heed, heaven has a justice: take this ring with ye,
This doting spell you gave me: too well Alinda,
Thou knew'st the virtue in't; too well I feel it:
Nay keep that too, it may sometimes remember ye,
When you are willing to forget who gave it,
And to what virtuous end.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Must I go from ye?
Of all the sorrow's sorrow has — must I part with ye?
Part with my noble mistress?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Or I with thee wench.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And part stained with opinion? Farewell lady,
Happy and blessed lady, goodness keep ye:
Thus your poor servant full of grief turns from ye,
For ever full of grief, for ever from ye.
I have no being now, no friends, no country,
I wander heaven knows whither, heaven knows how.
No life, now you are lost: only mine innocence,
That little left me of myself, goes with me,
That's all my bread and comfort. I confess madam,
Truly confess, the Duke has often courted me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And poured his soul into thee, won thee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Do you think so?
Well, time that told this tale, will tell my truth too,
And say ye had a faithful, honest servant:
The business of my life is now to pray for ye,
Pray for your virtuous loves; pray for your children,
When heaven shall make ye happy.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: How she wounds me?
Either I am undone, or she must go: take these with ye,
Some toys may do ye service; and this money;
And when ye want, I love ye not so poorly,
Not yet Alinda, that I would see ye perish.
Prithee be good, and let me hear: look on me,
I love those eyes yet dear; I have kissed thee,
And now I'll do't again: farewell Alinda,
I am too full to speak more, and too wretched. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You have my faith,
And all the world my fortune. Exit.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I would fain hear
What becomes of these two wenches:
And if I can, I will do 'em good. Enter gentleman passing over the stage.
Do you hear my honest friend?
He knows no such name:
What a world of business,
Which by interpretation are mere nothings,
These things have here? 'mass now I think on't better,
I wish he be not sent for one of them
To some of these by-lodgings: methought I saw
A kind of reference in his face to bawdry.
sp.stage: Enter gent. with a gentlewom. passing over the stage.
sp.l: He has her, but 'tis none of them: hold fast thief:
An excellent touzing knave. Mistress
You are to suffer your penance some half hour hence now
How far a fine court custard with plumbs it
Will prevail with one of these waiting gentlewomen,
They are taken with these soluble things exceedingly;
This is some yeoman oth' bottles now that has sent for her,
That she calls father: now woe to this ale incense.
By your leave sir.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Well sir; what's your pleasure with me?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You do not know the way to the maids lodgings?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes indeed do I sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: But you will not tell me?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: No indeed will not I, because you doubt it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: These are fine gimcracks: heigh, here comes another,
A haggon full of wine in's hand, I take it.
Well met my friend, is that wine?

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: Yes indeed is it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Faith I'll drink on't then.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: Ye may, because ye have sworn sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis very good, I'll drink a great deal now sir.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: I cannot help it sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I'll drink more yet.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: 'Tis in your own hands.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: There's your pot, I thank ye.
Pray let me drink again.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: Faith but ye shall not.
Now have I sworn I take it. Fare ye well sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: This is the finest place to live in I e'er entered. Enter lady.
Here comes a gentle woman, and alone; I'll to her.
Madam, my lord my master.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Who's your lord sir?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The lord Borosky, lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Pray excuse me:
Here's something for your pains: within this hour sir,
One of the choice young ladies shall attend him:
Pray let it be in that chamber juts out to the water;
'Tis private and convenient: do my humble service
To my honourable good lord, I beseech ye sir;
If it please you to visit a poor lady —
You carry the 'Behaviour of a noble gentleman,

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I shall be bold.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: 'Tis a good aptness in ye.
I lie here in the woodyard, the blue lodgings sir;
They call me merrily the lady of the — sir;
A little I know what belongs to a gentleman,
And if it please you take the pains. Exit.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Dear lady, take the pains?
Why a horse would not take the pains that thou requirest now,
To cleave old crabtree? one of the choice young ladies:
I would I had let this bawd go, she has frighted me;
I am cruelly afraid of one of my tribe now;
But if they will do, the devil cannot stop 'em.
Why should he have a young lady? are women now
Oth' nature of bottles, to be stopped with corks?
O the thousand little furies that fly here now?
How now captain? Enter Putsky.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: I come to seek you out sir,
And all the town I have travelled.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What's the news man?

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: That that concerns us all, and very nearly:
The Duke this night holds a great feast at court,
To which he bids for guests all his old counsellors,
And all his favourites: your father's sent for.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Why he is neither in council, nor in favour.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: That's it: have an eye now, or never, and a quick one,
An eye that must not wink from good intelligence.
I heard a bird sing, they mean him no good office.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Art sure he sups here? Enter ancient.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: Sure as 'tis day.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis like then:
How now, where hast thou been ancient?

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: Measuring the city:
I have left my brooms at gate here;
By this time the porter has stole 'em to sweep out rascals.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Brooms?

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: I have been crying brooms all the town over,
And such a mart I have made, there's no trade near it.
O the young handsome wenches, how they twittered,
When they but saw me shake my ware, and sing too;
Come hither master broom-man I beseech ye:
Good master broom-man hither cries another.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Thou art a mad fellow.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: They are all as mad as I: they all have trades now,
And roar about the streets like bull-beggars.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What company of soldiers are they?

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: By this means I have gathered
Above a thousand tall and hardy soldiers,
If need be colonel.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That need's come ancient,
And 'twas discreetly done: go, draw 'em presently,
But without suspicion: this night we shall need 'em;
Let 'em be near the court, let Putsky guide 'em;
And wait me for occasion: here I'll stay still.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: If it fall out we are ready; if not we are scattered:
I'll wait ye at an inch.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Do, farewell. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Are the soldiers still so mutinous?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: More than ever,
No law nor justice frights 'em: all the town over
They play new pranks and gambols: no man's person,
Of what degree soever, free from abuses:
And durst they do this, (Let your grace consider)
These monstrous, most offensive things, these villainies,
If not set on, and fed? if not by one
They honour more than you? and more awed by him?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Happily their own wants.

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: I offer to supply 'em,
And every hour make tender of their moneys:
They scorn it, laugh at me that offer it:
I fear the next device will be my life sir;
And willingly I'll give it, so they stay there.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Do you think lord Archas privy?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: More than thought,
I know it sir, I know they durst not do
These violent rude things, abuse the state thus,
But that they have a hope by his ambitions —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No more: he's sent for?

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: Yes, and will be here sure.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Let me talk further with you anon.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I'll wait sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Did you speak to the ladies?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: They'll attend your grace presently.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How do you like 'em?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: My eyes are too dull judges.
They wait here sir. Exit.Enter Honora and Viola.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Be you gone then: come in ladies.
Welcome toth' court sweet beauties; now the court shines,
When such true beams of beauty strike amongst us:
Welcome, welcome, even as your own joys welcome.
How do you like the court? how seems it to you?
Is't not a place created for all sweetness?
Why were you made such strangers to this happiness?
Barred the delights this holds? the richest jewels
Set never so well, if than not worn to wonder,
By judging eyes not set off, lose their lustre:
Your country shades are faint; blasters of beauty;
The manners like the place, obscure and heavy;
The rose buds of your beauties turn to cankers,
Eaten with inward thoughts: whilst there ye wander.
Here ladies, here, you were not made for cloisters,
Here is the sphere you move in: here shine nobly,
And by your powerful influence command all:
What a sweet modesty dwells round about 'em,
And like a nipping morn pulls in their blossoms?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Your grace speaks cunningly, you do not this,
I hope sir, to betray us, we are poor triumphs;
Nor can our loss of honour add to you sir:
Great men, and great thoughts, seek things great and worthy,
Subjects to make 'em live, and not to lose 'em;
Conquests so nobly won, can never perish;
We are two simple maids, untutored here sir;
Two honest maids, is that a sin at court sir?
Our breeding is obedience, but to good things,
To virtuous and to fair: what would you win on us?
Why do I ask that question, when I have found ye?
Your preamble has powered your heart out to us;
You would dishonour us; which in your translation
Here at the court reads thus, your grace would love us,
Most dear love us: stick us up for mistresses:
Most certain, there are thousands of our sex sir
That would be glad of this, and handsome women,
And crowd into this favour, fair young women,
Excellent beauty's sir: when ye have enjoyed 'em,
And sucked those sweets they have, what saints are these then?
What worship have they won? what name you guess sir,
What story added to their time, a sweet one?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: A brave spirited wench.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I'll tell your grace,
And tell ye true: ye are deceived in us two,
Extremely cozened sir: and yet in my eye
You are the handsom'st man I ever looked on,
The goodliest gentleman; take that hope with ye;
And were I fit to be your wife (So much I honour ye)
Trust me I would scratch for ye but I would have ye.
I would woo you then.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: She amazes me:
But how am I deceived?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O we are too honest,
Believe it sir, too honest, far too honest,
The way that you propound too ignorant,
And there is no meddling with us; for we are fools too,
Obstinate, peevish fools: if I would be ill,
And had a wantoness itch, to kick my heels up,
I would not leap into th'sun, and do't there,
That all the world might see me: an obscure shade sir,
Dark as the deed, there is no trusting light with it,
Nor that's that lighter far, vainglorious greatness.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You will love me as your friend?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I will honour ye,
As your poor humble handmaid serve, and pray for ye.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What says my little one; you are not to obstinate?
Lord how the blushes: here are truly fair souls:
Come you will be my love?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Good sir be good to me,
Indeed I'll do the best I can to please ye;
I do beseech your grace: alas I fear ye.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What shouldst thou fear?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Fie sir, this is not noble.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why do I stand entreating, where my power —

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You have no power, at least you ought to have none
In bad and beastly things: armed thus, I'll die here,
Before she suffer wrong.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Another Archas?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: His child sir, and his spirit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I'll deal with you then,
For here's the honour to be won: sit down sweet,
Prithee Honora sit.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Now ye entreat I will sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I do, and will deserve it.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: That's too much kindness.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Prithee look on me.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Yes: I love to see ye,
And could look on an age thus, and admire ye:
Whilst ye are good and temperate I dare touch ye,
Kiss your white hand.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why not my lips?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I dare sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I do not think ye dare.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I am no coward.
Do you believe me now? or now? or now sir?
You make me blush: but sure I mean no ill sir:
It had been fitter you had kissed me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: That I'll do too.
What hast thou wrought into me?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I hope all goodness:
Whilst ye are thus, thus honest, I dare do any thing,
Thus hang about your neck, and thus dote on ye;
Bless those fair lights: hell take me if I durst not —
But good sir pardon me. Sister come hither,
Come hither, fear not wench: come hither, blush not,
Come kiss the prince, the virtuous prince, the good prince:
Certain he is excellent honest.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thou wilt make me —

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Sit down, and hug him softly.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Fie Honora,
Wanton Honora; is this the modesty,
The noble chastity your onset showed me,
At first charge beaten back? Away.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thank ye:
Upon my knees I pray, heaven too may thank ye;
Ye have deceived me cunningly, yet nobly
Ye have cozened me: in all your hopeful life yet,
A scene of greater honour, you never acted:
I knew fame was a liar, too long, and loud tongued,
And now I have found it: oh my virtuous master.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My virtuous master too.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Now you are thus,
What shall become of me let fortune cast for't.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I'll be that fortune, if I live Honora,Enter Alin.
Thou hast done a cure upon me, counsel could not.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Here take your ring sir, and whom ye mean to ruin,
Give it to her next; I have paid for't dear.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: A ring to her?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why frowns my fair Alinda?
I have forgotten both these again.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Stand still sir,
Ye have that violent killing fire upon ye,
Consumes all honour, credit, faith.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: My royal mistress favour towards me,
Woe-worth ye sir, ye have poisoned, blasted.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I sweet?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You have taken that unmanly liberty,
Which in a worse man, is vainglorious feigning,
And killed my truth.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Upon my life 'tis false wench.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ladies,
Take heed, ye have a cunning gamester,
A handsome, and a high; come store with antidotes,
He has infections else will fire your bloods.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Prithee Alinda hear me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Words steeped in honey,
That will so melt into your minds, buy chastity,
A thousand ways, a thousand knots to tie ye;
And when he has bound ye his, a thousand ruins.
A poor lost woman ye have made me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I'll maintain thee,
And nobly too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That gin's too weak to take me:
Take heed, take heed young ladies: still take heed,
Take heed of promises, take heed of gifts,
Of forced feigned sorrows, sighs, take heed.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: By all that's mine, Alinda —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Swear
By your mischiefs:
Oh whither shall I go?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Go back again,
I'll force her take thee, love thee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Fare ye well sir,
I will not curse ye; only this dwell with ye,
Whenever you love, a false belief light on ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: We'll take our leaves too sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Part all the world now,
Since she is gone.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You are crooked yet, dear master,
And still I fear —Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I am vexed,
And some shall find it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis strange
To me to see the court, and welcome:
Oh royal place, how have I loved and served thee?
Who lies on this side, knowest thou?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The lord Burris.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thou hast named a gentleman
I stand much bound to.
I think he sent the casket sir?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The same sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: An honest minded man, a noble courtier:
The Duke made perfect choice when he took him.
Go you home, I shall hit the way
Without a guide now.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: You may want something sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Only my horses,
Which after supper let the groom wait with:
I'll have no more attendance here.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Your will sir? Exit.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: You are well met here sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How now boy,
How dost thou?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I should ask
You that question: how do you sir?
How do you feel yourself?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why well, and lusty.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What do you here then?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why I am sent for
To supper with the Duke.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Have you no meat at home?
Or do you long to feed as hunted deer do,
In doubt and fear?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I have an excellent stomach,
And can I use it better
Than among my friend's boy?
How do the wenches?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They do well enough sir,
They know the worst by this time: pray be ruled sir,
Go home again, and if ye have a supper
Eat it in quiet there: this is no place for ye,
Especially at this time,
Take my word for't.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: May be they'll drink hard;
I could have drunk my share boy.
Though I am old, I will not out.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I hope you will.
Hark in your ear: the court's
Too quick of hearing.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Not mean me well?
Thou art abused and cozened.
Away, away.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: To that end sir I tell ye.
Away, if ye love yourself.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Who dare do these things,
That ever heard of honesty?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Old gentleman,
Take a fool's counsel.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis a fool's indeed;
A very fools: thou hast more of
These flams in thee, these musty doubts:
Is't fit the Duke send for me,
And honour me to eat within his presence,
And I, like a tall fellow, play at bopeep
With his pleasure?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Take heed
Of bopeep with your pate, your pate sir,
I speak plain language now.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: If 'twere not here,
Where reverence bids-me hold,
I would so swinge thee, thou rude,
Unmannered knave; take from his bounty,
His honour that he gives me, to beget
Saucy, and sullen fears?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You are not mad sure:
By this fair light, I speak
But what is whispered,
And whispered for a truth.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A dog: drunken people,
That in their pot see visions,
And turn states, madmen and children:
Prithee do not follow me;
I tell thee I am angry:
Do not follow me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am as angry
As you for your heart.
I and as wilful too: go, like a woodcock,
And thrust your neck ith' noose.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I'll kill thee.
And thou speakst but three words more.
Do not follow me. Exit.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: A strange old foolish fellow: I shall hear yet,
And if I do not my part hiss at me. Exit.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter two servants preparing a banquet.

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.l: Believe me fellow here will be lusty drinking.
Many a washt pate in wine I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: I am glad the old general's come: upon my conscience
That joy will make half the court drunk. Hark the trumpets,
They are coming on; away.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: We'll have a rouse too. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Duke, Archas, Burris, Borosky, attend. Gent,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Come seat yourselves: lord Archas sit you there.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis far above my worth.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I'll have it so:
Are all things ready?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: All the guards are set,
The court gates shut.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Then do as I prescribed ye.
Be sure no further.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I shall well observe ye.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come bring some wine: here's to my sister gentlemen;
A health, and mirth to all.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Pray fill it full sir.
'Tis a high health to virtue: here lord Burris,
A maiden health: you are most fit to pledge it,
You have a maiden soul, and much I honour it.
Passion o'me, ye are sad man.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How now Burris.
Go to, no more of this.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Take the rouse freely,
'Twill warm your blood, and make ye fit for jollity.
Your grace's pardon: when we get a cup sir,
We old men prate a pace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Mirth makes a banquet;
As you love me no more.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I thank your grace.
Give me it; lord Borosky.

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: I have ill brains sir.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Damnable ill, I know it.

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: But I'll pledge sir
This virtuous health. Enter two servants with cloaks.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: The more unfit for thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come, bring out robes, and let my guests look nobly,
Fit for my love, and presence: begin downward.
Off with your cloaks, take new.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Your grace deals truly
Like a munificent prince, with your poor subjects,
Who would not fight for you? what cold dull coward
Durst seek to save his life when you would ask it?
Begin a new health in your new adornments,
The Dukes, the royal Dukes: ha, what have I got
Sir? ha! the robe of death!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You have deserved it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The livery of the grave? do you start all from me?
Do I smell of earth already? Sir look on me,
And like a man; is this your entertainment?
Do you bid your worthiest guests to bloody banquets.
A guard upon me too? this is too foul play
Boy to thy good, thine honour; thou wretched ruler,
Thou son of fools and flatterers, heir of hypocrites,
Am I served in a hearse that saved ye all?
Are ye men or devils? do ye gape upon me,
Wider, and swallow all my services?
Entomb them first, my faith next, than my integrity,
And let these struggle with your mangy minds,
Your seared, and sealed up consciences, till ye burst.

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: These words are death.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No those deeds that want rewards, sirrah,
Those battles I have fought, those horrid dangers,
Leaner than death, and wilder than destruction,
I have marched upon, these honoured wounds, time's story,
The blood I have lost, the youth, the sorrows suffered,
These are my death, these that can never be recompensed,
These that ye sit a brooding on like toads,
Sucking from my deserts the sweets and favours,
And render me no pay again but poisons.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: The proud vain soldier thou hast set —

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thou liest.
Now by my little time of life liest basely,
Maliciously and loudly: how I scorn thee?
If I had swollen the soldier, or intended
As act in person, leaning to dishonour,
As ye would fain have forced me, witness heaven,
Where clearest understanding of all truth is,
(For these are spiteful men, and know no piety)
When Olin came, grim Olin, when his marches,
His last incursions made the city sweat,
And drove before him, as a storm drives hail,
Such showers of frosted fears, shook all your heartstrings;
Then when the Volga trembled at his terror,
And hid his seven curled heads, afraid of bruising,
By his armed horses hooves; had I been false then,
Or blown a treacherous fire into the soldier,
Had but one spark of villainy lived within me,
You'd had some shadow for this black about me.
Where was your soldiership? why went not you out?
And all your right honourable valour with ye?
Why met ye not the tartar, and defied him?
Drew your dead-doing sword, and buckled with him?
Shot through his squadrons like a fiery meteor?
And as we see a dreadful clap of thunder
Rend the stiff hearted oaks, and toss their roots up:
Why did not you so charge him? you were sick then,
You that dare taint my credit slipped to bed then,
Stewing and fainting with the fears ye had,
A whoreson shaking fit oppressed your lordship:
Blush coward knave, and all the world hiss at thee.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Exceed not my command. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I shall observe it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Are you gone too? Come weep not honest Burris,
Good loving lord, no more tears: 'tis not his malice,
This fellow's malice, nor the Duke's displeasure,
By bold bad men, crowded into his nature,
Can startle me: fortune never razed this fort yet:
I am the same, the same man, living, dying;
The same mind to 'em both, I poise thus equal;
Only the juggling way that told me to it,
The Judas way, to kiss me, bid me welcome,
And cut my throat, a little sticks upon me.
Farewell, commend me to his grace, and tell him,
The world is full of servants, he may have many:
And some I wish him honest: he's undone else:
But such another doting Archas never,
So tried and touched a faith: farewell for ever.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Be strong my lord: you must not go thus lightly.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now, what's to do? what says the law unto me?
Give me my great offence that speaks me guilty,

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Laying aside a thousand petty matters,
As scorns, and insolences both from yourself and followers,
Which you put first fire to, and these are deadly,
I come to one main cause, which though it carries
A strangeness in the circumstance, it carries death too,
Not to be pardoned neither: ye have done a sacrilege.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: High heaven defend me man: how, how Borosky?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ye have taken from the temple those vowed arms,
The holy ornament you hung up there,
No absolution of your vow, no order
From holy church to give 'em back unto you
After they were purified from war, and rested
From blood, made clean by ceremony: from the altar
You snatched 'em up again, again ye wore 'em,
Again you stained 'em, stained your vow, the church too,
And robbed it of that right was none of yours sir,
For which the law requires your head, ye know it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Those arms I fought in last?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: God a mercy,
Thou hast hunted out a notable cause to kill me:
A subtle one: I die, for saving all you;
Good sir remember if you can, the necessity,
The suddenness of time, the state all stood in;
I was entreated to, kneeled to, and prayed to,
The Duke himself, the princes, all the nobles,
The cries of infants, bedrid fathers, virgins;
Prithee find out a better cause, a handsomer,
This will undo thee too; people will spit at thee,
The devil himself would be ashamed of this cause;
Because my haste made me forget the ceremony,
The present danger everywhere , must my life satisfy?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: It must, and shall.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: O base ungrateful people,
Have ye no other sword to cut my throat with
But mine own nobleness? I confess, I took 'em,
The vow not yet absolved, I hung 'em up with:
Wore 'em, fought in 'em, gilded 'em again
In the fierce Tartar's bloods; for you I took 'em,
For your peculiar safety, lord, for all,
I wore 'em for my country's health, that groaned then:
Took from the temple, to preserve the temple;
That holy place, and all the sacred monuments,
The reverent shrines of saints, adored and honoured,
Had been consumed to ashes, their own sacrifice,
Had I been slack, or stayed that absolution.
No priest had lived to give it; my own honour
Cure of my country murder me?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: No, no sir,
I shall force that from ye, will make this cause light too,
Away with him: I shall pluck down that heart sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Break it thou mayest; but if it bend, for pity,
Dogs, and kits eat it: come I am honour's martyr. Ex.

div.head: Scene 6.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Exceed my warrant?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You know he loves him not.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He dares as well meet death, as do it, eat wildfire,
Through a few fears I mean to try his goodness,
That I may find him fit, to wear here Burris;
I know Borosky hates him, to death hates him,
I know he's a serpent too, a swollen oneNoise within.
But I have pulled his sting out; what noise is that?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Within.down with 'em, down with 'em, down with the gates.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Within.stand, stand, stand.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.p: Within.fire the palace before ye.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Upon my life the soldier, sir, the soldier,
A miserable time is come. Enter gent.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O save him,
Upon my knees, my heart's knees, save lord Archas,
We are undone else.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Dares he touch his body?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: He racks him fearfully, most fearfully.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Away Burris,
Take men, and take him from him; clap him up,
And if I live, I'll find a strange death for him:Ex. Bur.
Are the soldiers broke in?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: By this time sure they are sir,
They beat the gates extremely, beat the people.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Get me a guard about me; make sure the lodgings
And speak the soldiers fair.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Pray heaven that take sir. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Putsky, ancient, soldiers, with torches.

sp.speaker: Put,
sp.l: Give us the general, we'll fire the court else,
Render him safe and well,

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: Do not fire the cellar,
There's excellent wine in't captain, and though it be cold whether,
I do not love it mulled; bring out the general,
We'll light ye, such a bonfire else; where are ye?
Speak, or we'll toss your turrets, peep out of your hives
We'll smoke ye else: is not that a nose there?
Put out that note again, and if thou dar'st
But blow it before us: now he creeps out on's but rough.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: Give us the general. Enter gent.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes, gentlemen;
Or any thing ye can desire.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: You musk-cat
Cordevan-skin, we will not take your answer.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Where is the Duke? speak suddenly, and send him hither.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: Or we'll so fry your buttocks.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good sweet gentlemen —

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: We are neither good, nor sweet, we are soldiers
And you miscreants that abuse the general,
Give fire my boys 'tis a dark evening,
Let's light 'em to their lodgings.

div.stage: Enter Olimpia, Honora, Viola, Theodore, women.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Good brother be not fierce.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I will not hurt her,
Fear not sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'May do what you please sit,
I have a sorrow that exceeds all yours,
And more, contemns all danger. Enter Duke above

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Where is the Duke?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He's here; what would ye soldiers? wherefore troop ye
Like mutinous madmen thus?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Give me my father.

sp.speaker: Put. ancient
sp.l: Give us our general.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Set him here before us,
Ye see the pledge we have got; ye see these torches;
All shall to ashes, as I live, immediately,
A thousand lives for one.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: But hear me?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: No, we come not to dispute. Enter Archas and Bur.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: By heaven I swear he's racked and whipped.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O my poor father!

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Burn, kill, and burn.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Hold, hold I say: hold soldiers,
On your allegiance hold.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: We must not.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Hold:
I swear by heaven he it a barbarous traitor stirs first,
A villain, and a stranger to obedience,
Never my soldier more, nor friend to honour:
Why did you use your old man thus? thus cruelly
Torture his poor weak body? I ever loved ye.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Forget me in these wrongs, most noble Archas.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I have balm enough for all my hurts: weep no more sir,
A satisfaction for a thousand sorrows:
I do believe ye innocent, a good man,
And heaven forgive that naughty thing that wronged me.
Why look ye willed my friends? why stare ye one me?
I charge ye as ye are men, my men, my lovers,
As ye are honest faithful men, fair soldiers,
Let down your anger: is not this our sovereign,
The head of mercy, and of law? who dares then,
But rebels scorning law, appear thus violent?
Is this a place for swords? for threatening fires?
The reverence of this house dares any touch,
But with obedient knees, and pious duties?
Are we not all his subjects? all sworn to him?
Has not he power to punish our offences?
And do not we daily fall into 'em? assure yourselves
I did offend and highly, grievously,
This good sweet prince I offended, my life forfeited,
Which yet his mercy, and his old love met with,
And only let me feel his light rod this way:
Ye are to thank him for your general,
Pray for his life, and fortune: sweat your bloods for him.
You are offenders too, daily offenders,
Proud insolences dwell in your hearts, and ye do 'em,
Do 'em against his peace, his law, his person;
Ye see he only sorrows for your sins,
And where his power might persecute, forgives ye:
For shame put up your swords, for honesty,
For orde's sake and whose ye are, my soldiers,
Be not so rude.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They have drawn blood from ye sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: That was the blood rebelled, the naughty blood,
The proud provoking blood; 'tis well 'tis out boy;
Give you example first; draw out, and orderly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Good brother do.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Honest and high example,
As thou wilt have my blessing follow thee,
Inherit all mine honours: thank ye Theodore,
My worthy son.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: If harm come, thank yourself sir;
I must obey ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Captain, you know the way now:
A good man, and a valiant, you were ever,
Inclined to honest things: I thank ye captain. Ex. soul.
Soldiers, I thank ye all: and love me still,
But do not love me so you lose allegiance,
Love that above your lives: once more I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Bring him to rest, and let our cares wait on him;
Thou excellent old man, thou top of honour,
Where justice, and obedience only build,
Thou stock of virtue, how am I bound to love thee?
In all thy noble ways to follow thee?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Remember him that vexed him sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Remember?
When I forget that villain, and to pay him
For all his mischiefs, may all good thoughts forget me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am very sore,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Bring him to bed with ease gentlemen,
For every stripe I'll drop a tear to wash 'em,
And in my sad repentance —

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis too much,
I have a life yet left to gain that love sir.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How does lord Archas yet?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: But weak an't please ye,
Yet all the helps that art can, are applied to him;
His heart's untouched, and whole yet; and no doubt sir,
His mind being found, his body soon will follow.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O that base knave that wronged him, without leave too;
But I shall find an hour to give him thanks for't;
He's fast I hope?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: As fast as irons can keep him:
But the most fearful wretch —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He has a conscience,
A cruel stinging one I warrant him,
A loaden one: but what news of the soldier?
I did not like their parting, 'twas too sullen.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: That they keep still, and I fear a worse clap:
They are drawn out of the town, and stand in counsels,
Hatching unquiet thoughts, and cruel purposes:
I went myself unto 'em, talked with the captains,
Whom I found fraught with nothing but loud murmurs,
And desperate curses, sounding these words often
Like trumpets to their angers: we are ruined,
Our services turned to disgraces, mischiefs,
Our brave old general, like one had pilfered,
Tortured, and whipped: the colonel's eyes like torches,
Blaze every where and fright fair peace.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yet worse sir:
The news is currant now, they mean to leave ye,
Leave their allegiance: and under Olin's charge
The bloody enemy march straight against ye.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I have heard this too sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This must be prevented,
And suddenly, and warily.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: 'Tis time sir,
But what to minister, or how?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Go in with me,
And there we'll think upon't: such blows as these,
Equal defences ask, else they displease. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Lord, what a coil has here been with these soldiers?
They are cruel fellows.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: And yet methought we found 'em
Handsome enough; I'll tell thee true Petesca,
I looked for other manner of dealings from 'em,
And had prepared myself; but where's my lady?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: In her old dumps within: monstrous melancholy;
Sure she was mad of this wench.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: And she had been a man,
She would have been a great deal madder, I am glad she is shifted.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Twas a wicked thing for me to betray her,Ent. Alinda
And yet I must confess she stood in our lights,
What young thing's this?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Good morrow beauteous gentlewomen:
Pray you is the Princess stirring yet?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: He has her face.

sp.speaker: Pedlar
sp.l: Her very tongue, and tone too: her youth upon him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I guess ye to be the Princess women.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Yes, we are sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Pray is there not a gentlewoman waiting on her grace,
Ye call Alinda?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The devil sure in her shape.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: I have heard her tell my lady of a brother,
An only brother that she had: in travel —

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Mas, I remember that: this may be he too:
I would this thing would serve her. Enter Olimpia

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: So would I wench,
We should love him better sure: sir, here's the princes,
She best can satisfy ye.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How I love that presence!
O blessed eyes how nobly shines your comforts!

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: We know not madam:
He asked us for your grace: and as we guess it,
He is Alinda's brother.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Ha? let me mark him:
My grief has almost blinded me: her brother?
By Venus, he has all her sweetness upon him:
Two silver drops of dew, were never liker.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Gracious lady —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: That pleasant pipe he has too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Being my happiness to pass by this way,
And having as I understand by letters,
A sister in your virtuous service madam —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O now my heart, my heart aches.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: All the comfort
My poor youth has, all that my hopes have built me,
I thought it my first duty, my best service
Here to arrive first, humbly to thank your grace
For my poor first, humbly to thank your nobleness,
That bounteous goodness in ye.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'Tis he certainly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That spring of favour to her; with my life madam
If any such most happy means might meet me,
To show my thankfulness.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What have I done fool?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: She came a stranger to your grace, no courtier;
Nor of that curious breed befits your service,
Yet one I dare assure my soul, that loved ye
Before she saw ye; doted on your virtues;
Before she knew those fair eyes longed to read 'em,
You only had her prayers, you her wishes;
And that one hope to be yours once, preserved her,

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I have done wickedly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A little beauty,
Such as a cottage breeds, she brought along with her;
And yet our country eyes esteemed it much too:
But for her beauteous mind forget great lady
I am her brother, and let me speak a stranger,
Since she was able to beget a thought, 'twas honest,
The daily study how to fit your services,
Truly to tread that virtuous path you walk in,
So fired her honest soul, we thought her sainted;
I presume she is still the same: I would fain see her,
For madam, 'tis no little love I owe her.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Sir, such a maid there was, I had —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: There was madam?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O my poor wench: eyes, I will ever curse ye
For your credulity. Alinda.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That's her name, madam.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Give me a little leave sir to lament her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Is she dead lady?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Dead sir, to my service.
She is gone, pray ye ask no further,

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I obey madam:
Gone? now must I lament too: said ye gone, madam?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Gone, gone for ever.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That's a cruel saying:
Her honour too?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Prithee look angry on me,
And if thou ever lovedst her, spit upon me;
Do something like a brother, like a friend,
And do not only say thou lovest her —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ye amaze me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I ruined her, I wronged her, I abused her;
Poor innocent soul, I flung her; sweet Alinda,
Thou virtuous maid, my soul now calls thee virtuous.
Why do ye not rail now at me?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: For what lady?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Call me base treacherous woman.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Heaven defend me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Rashly I thought her false, and put her from me,
Rashly, and madly I betrayed her modesty,
Put her to wand, heaven knows where: nay, more sir,
Stuck a black brand upon her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Twas not well lady,

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'Twas damnable: she loving me so dear,
Never poor wench loved so: sir, believe me,
'Twas the most duteous wench, the best companion,
When I was pleased, the happiest, and the gladdest,
The modestest sweet nature dwelled within her:
I saw all this, I knew all this. I loved it,
I doted on it too, and yet I killed it:
Oh what have I forsaken? what have I lost?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Madam, I'll take my leave, since she is wand'ring,
'Tis fit I know no rest.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Will you go too sir?
I have not wronged you yet, if you dare trust me,
For yet I love Alinda there, I honour her,
I love to look upon those eyes that speak her,
To read that face again, modesty keep me,
Alinda, in that shape: but why should you trust me,
'Twas I betrayed your sister, I undid her;
And believe me, gentle youth, 'tis I weep for her:
Appoint what penance you please: but stay then,
And see me perform it; ask what honour this place
Is able to heap on ye, or what wealth:
If following me will like ye, my care of ye,
Which for your sister's sake, for your own goodness —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Not all the honour earth has, now she's gone lady,
Not all the favour; yet if I sought preferment,
Under your bounteous grace I would only take it.
Peace rest upon ye: one sad tear every day
For poor Alinda's sake, 'tis fit ye pay,Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: A thousand noble youth, and when I sleep,
Even in my silver slumbers still I'll weep. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Have ye been with 'em?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes, and 't please your grace,
But no persuasion serves 'em, nor no promise,
They are fearful angry, and by this time sir,
Upon their march to the enemy -

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: They must be stopped. Enter Burris.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Ay, but what force is able? and what leader —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How now, have you been with Archas?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Yes, an't please ye,
And told him all: he frets like a chased lion,
And calls for his arms: and all those honest courtiers
That dare draw swords.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is he able to do any thing?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: His mind is well enough; and where his charge is,
Let him be never so sore, 'tis a full army.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Who commands the rebels?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: The young colonel,
That makes the old man almost mad: he swears sir,
He will not spare his son's head for the dukedom.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is the court in arms?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: As fast as they can bustle,
Every man mad to go now: inspired strangely,
As if they were to force the enemy,
I beseech your grace to give me leave.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Pray go sir,
And look to the old man well; take up all fairly,
And let no blood be spilt; take general pardons,
And quench this fury with fair peace.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I shall sir,
Or seal it with my service; they are villains;
The court is up: good sir, go strengthen 'em,
Your royal sight will make 'em scorn all dangers;
The general needs no proof.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come let's go view 'em. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter Theodore, Putsky, ancient, soldiers, drums, and colours.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis known we are up, and marching: no submission,
No promise of base peace can cure our maladies,
We have suffered beyond all repair of honour:
Your valiant old man's whipped; whipped gentlemen,
Whipped like a slave: that flesh that never trembled,
Nor shrunk one sinew at a thousand charges,
That noble body ribbed in arms, the enemy
So often shook at, and then shunned like thunder,
That bodies torn with lashes.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: Let's turn head.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Turn nothing gentlemen, let's march on fairly,
Unless they charge us.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Think still of his abuses,
And keep your angers.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: He was whipped like a top,
I never saw a whore so laced: court school-butter?
Is this their diet? I'll dress 'em one running banquet:
What oracle can alter us? did not we see him?
See him we loved?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And though we did obey him,
Forced by his reverence for that time; is't fit gentlemen?
My noble friends, is't fit we men, and soldiers,
Live to endure this, and look on too?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Forward:
They may call back the sun as soon, stay time,
Prescribe a law to death, as we endure this.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They will make ye all fair promises.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: We care not.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Use all their arts upon ye.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: Hang all their arts.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: And happily they'll bring him with 'em.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: March apace then,
He is old and cannot overtake us.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Say he do.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: We'll run away with him: they shall never see him more:
The truth is, we'll hear nothing, stop at nothing,
Consider nothing but our way; believe nothing,
Not though they say their prayers: be content with nothing,
But the knocking out their brains: and last, do nothing
But ban 'em and curse 'em, till we come to kill 'em.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Remove then forwards bravely; keep your minds whole,
And the next time we face 'em, shall be fatal. Ex.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter Archas, Duke, Bur. gent. and sould.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Peace to your grace; take rest sir, they are before us. Ex. Du.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: They are sir, and upon the march

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Lord Burris,
Take you those horse and coast 'em: upon the first advantage,
If they will not slack their march, charge 'em up roundly,
By that time I'll come in.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I'll do it truly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: How do you feel yourself sir?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Well, I thank ye;
A little weak, but anger shall supply that;
You will all stand bravely to it?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Whilst we have lives sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ye speak like gentlemen; I'll make the knaves know,
The proudest, and the strongest hearted rebel,
They have a law to live in, and they shall have;
Beat up a pace, by this time he is upon 'em,Drum within,
And sword, but hold me now, thou shalt play ever. Ex.
sp.stage: Enter drums beating, Theodore, put sky, ancient, and their soldiers.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Stand, stand, stand close, and sure;Enter Bur. and 1 or 2 soul.
The horse will charge us.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: Let 'em come one, we have provender sit for 'em.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Here comes lord Burris sir, I think to parley.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You are welcome noble sir, I hope to our part.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: No, valiant colonel, I am come to chide ye,
To pity ye; to kill ye, if these fail me;
Fie, what dishonour seek ye? what black infamy!
Why do ye draw out thus? draw all shame with ye?
Are these fit cares in subjects? I command ye
Lay down your arms again, move in that peace,
That fair obedience you were bred in.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Charge us?
We come not here to argue.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Charge up bravely,
And hotly too, we have hot spleens to meet ye,Enter Ar. gent. and soul.
Hot as the shames are offered us.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Look behind ye.
Do you see that old man? do you know him soldiers?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Your father sir, believe me —

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You know his marches,
You have seen his executions: is it yet peace?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: We'll die here first.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Farewell: you'll hear on's presently.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stay Burris: this is too poor, too beggarly a body
To bear the honour of a charge from me,
A sort of tattered rebels; go provide gallows;
Ye are troubled with hot heads, I'll cool ye presently:
These look like men that were my soldiers
Now I behold 'em nearly, and more narrowly,
My honest friends: where got they these fair figures?
Where did they steal these shapes?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: They are struck already.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Do you see that fellow there; that goodly rebel?
He looks as like a captain, I loved tenderly:
A fellow of a faith indeed.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: He has shamed him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: And that that bears the colours there, most certain
So like an ancient of mine own, a brave fellow,
A loving and obedient, that believe me Burris,
I am amazed and troubled: and were it not
I know the general goodness of my people,
The duty, and the truth, the steadfast honesty,
And am assured they would as soon turn devils
As rebels to allegiance, for mine honour.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: Here needs no wars.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I pray forgive us sir.

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.l: Good general forgive us, or use your sword,
Your words are double death.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Good noble general.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Pray sir be merciful.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Weep out your shames first,
Ye make me fool for company: fie soldiers,
My soldiers too, and play these tricks: what's he there?
Sure I have seen his face too; yes, most certain
I have a son, but I hope he is not here now,
'Would much resemble this man, wondrous near him,
Just of his height and making too, you seem a leader.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Good sir, do not shame me more: I know your anger,
And less than death, I look not for.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You shall be my charge sir, it seems you want foes,
When you would make your friends your enemies:
A running blood ye have, but I shall cure ye.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Good sir —

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No more good lord: beat forward soldiers:
And you, march in the rear, you have lost your places. Ex.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You shall not be thus sullen still, with me sister
You do the most unnobly to be angry,
For as I have a soul, I never touched her,
I never yet knew one unchaste thought in her:
I must confess, I loved her: as who would not?
I must confess I doted on her strangely,
I offered all, yet so strong was her honour,
So fortified as fair, no hope could reach her,
And whilst the world beheld this, and confirmed it,
Why would you be so jealous?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Good sir pardon me,
I feel sufficiently my folly's penance,
And am ashamed, that shame a thousand sorrows
Feed on continually, would I had never seen her,
Or with a clearer judgement looked upon her,
She was too good for me, so heavenly good sir,
Nothing but heaven can love that soul sufficiently,Enter Burris.
Where I shall see her once again.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No more tears,
If she be within the dukedom, we'll recover her:
Welcome lord Burris, fair news I hope.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: Most fair sir,
Without one drop of blood these wars are ended,
The soldier cooled again, indeed ashamed sir,
And all his anger ended.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Where's lord Archas?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Not far off sir: with him his valiant son,
Head of this fire, but now a prisoner,
