And if by your sweet mercy not prevented,
I fear some fatal stroke. Drums.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I hear the drums beat,
Welcome, my worthy friend.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stand where ye are sir,
Even as you love your country, move not forward,
Nor plead for peace, till I have done a justice,
A justice on this villain; none of mine now,
A justice on this rebel.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O my brother.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: This fatal firebrand —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Forget not old man,
He is thy son of thine own blood.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: In these veins
No treachery e'er harboured yet, no mutiny,
I never gave life to lewd and headstrong rebels.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Tis his first fault.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Not of a thousand sir,
Or were it so, it is a fault so mighty,
So strong against the nature of all mercy,
His mother were she living, would not weep for him,
He dare not say he would live.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I must not sir,
Whilst you say 'tis not fit: your grace's mercy
Not to my life applied, but to my fault sit,
The world's forgiveness next, last, on my knees sir,
I humbly beg,
Do not take from me yet the name of father,
Strike me a thousand blows, but let me die yours.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: He moves my heart: I must be sudden with him,
I shall grow faint else, in my execution;
Come, come sir, you have seen death; now meet him bravely.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Hold, hold I say, a little hold, consider
Thou hast no more sons Archas to inherit thee.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes sir, I have another, and a nobler:
No treason shall inherit me: young Archas
A boy, as sweet as young, my brother breeds him,
My noble brother Briskie, breeds him nobly,
Him let your favour find: give him your honour.
sp.stage: Enter Putsky (Alias Briskie) and Alinda (Alias Archas.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Thou hast no child left Archas, none to inherit thee
If thou strik'st that stroke now: behold young Archas;
Behold thy brother here, thou bloody brother,
As bloody to this sacrifice as thou art:
Heave up thy sword, and mine's heaved up: strike Archas,
And I'll strike too, as suddenly, as deadly:
Have mercy, and I'll have mercy: the Duke gives it,
Look upon all these, how they weep it from thee,
Choose quickly, and begin.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: On your obedience,
On your allegiance save him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Take him to ye,Soul. shout.
And sirrah, be an honest man, ye have reason:
I thank ye worthy brother; welcome child,
Mine own sweet child.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why was this boy concealed thus?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Your grace's pardon:
Fearing the vow you made against my brother
And that your anger would not only light
On him, but find out all his family,
This young boy, to preserve from after danger,
Like a young wench, hither I brought; myself
In the habit of an ordinary captain
Disguised, got entertainment, and served here
That I might still be ready to all fortunes:
The boy your grace took, nobly entertained him,
But thought a girl, Alinda, madam.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Stand away,
And let me look upon him.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My young mistress?
This is a strange metamorphosis, Alinda?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Your grace's humble servant.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come hither sister:
I dare yet scarce believe mine eyes? how they view one another?
Dost thou not love this boy well?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I should lie else,
Trust me, extremely lie sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Didst thou never wish Olimpia,
It might be thus?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: A thousand times.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Here take him:
Nay, do not blush: I do not jest; kiss sweetly:
Boy, ye kiss faintly boy; heaven give ye comfort;
Teach him, he'll quickly learn: there's two hearts eased now.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You do me too much honour sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No Archas,
But all I can, I will; can you love me? speak truly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Yes sir, dear.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come hither Viola, can you love this man?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I'll do the best I can sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Seal it Burris:
We'll all to church together instantly:
And then a use for boys; stay, bring Borosky. Enter Borosky
I had almost forgotten that lump of mischief.
There Archas, take the enemy to honour,
The knave to worth: do with him what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Then to my sword again; you to your prayers;
Wash off your villainies, you feel the burden.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Forgive me ere I die, most honest Archas;
'Tis too much honour that I perish thus;
Oh strike my faults to kill them, that no memory,
No black and blasted infamy hereafter —

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Come, are ye ready?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: And truly penitent, to make your way straight?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Thus I wash off my sins.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stand up, and live then,
And live an honest man; I scorn men's ruins:
Take him again, sir, try him: and believe
This thing will be a perfect man.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I take him.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: And when I fail those hopes, heavens hopes fail me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You are old: no more wars father:
Theodore take you the charge, be general.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: All good bless ye.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And my good father, you dwell in my bosom,
From you rise all my good thoughts: when I would think
And examine time for one that's fairly noble,
And the same man through all the straits of virtue,
Upon this silver book I'll look, and read him.
Now forward merrily to Hymen's rights,
To joys, and revels, sports, and he that can
Most honour Archas, is the noblest man. Exeunt.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: We need not noble gentlemen to invite
Attention, preinstruct you who did write
This worthy story, being confident
The mirth joined with grave matter, and intent
To yield the hearers profit, with delight,
Will speak the maker: and to do him right,
Would ask a genius like to his; the age
Mourning his loss, and our now widowed stage
In vain lamenting ▪ I could add, so far
Behind him the most modern writers are,
That when they would commend him, their best praise
Ruins the buildings which they strive to raise,
To his best memory, so much a friend
Presumes to write, secure 'twill not offend
The living that are modest, with the rest
That may repine he cares not to contest.
This debt to Fletcher paid; it is professed
By us the actors, we will do our best
To send such favouring friends, as hither come
To grace the scane, pleased, and contented home.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: Though something well assured, few here repent
Three hours of precious time, or money spent
On our endeavours, yet not to rely
Too much upon our care, and industry,
'Tis fit we should ask, but a modest way
How you approve our action in the play.
If you vouchsafe to crown it with applause,
It is your bounty, and you give us cause
Hereafter with a general consent
To study, as becomes us, your content.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
